Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the idea that seniors and the disabled will have to stand in front of a "death panel" to determine their worthiness of healthcare.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that there is a subjective judgment of "level of productivity in society" that will be used to determine healthcare eligibility.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no panel in any version of the healthcare bills in Congress that judges a person's "level of productivity in society" to determine their worthiness of healthcare.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to substantiate the existence of a "death panel" or subjective judgment of worthiness in healthcare.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim overlooks the alternative explanation that comparative effectiveness research is not about evaluating patients for "worthiness" but rather finding out which treatments work better than others.
